intro: Sorghum bicolor var. obovatum, commonly known as the narrow-leaf sorghum, is a variant of sorghum characterized by its narrow, obovate leaves. It is a member of the grass family (Poaceae) and is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters and produces panicles of small, two-lobed flowers. It thrives in warm climates with well-drained soils and is often cultivated for its grain or as a forage crop. Its botanical features make it adaptable to various environmental conditions, contributing to its agricultural significance.
